0.title: Rubix Cube
0.description: As of January 2009, 350 million cubes had been sold worldwide.

1.title: Santa's Mail
1.description: In 2002, Bryon Reese launched Santa Mail. By 2009 Santa Mail had responded to nearly 300,000 children

2.title: SendaBall
2.description: A company started by 2 sisters in 2003 because they wanted to send something other than a card. So far, SENDaBALL has racked up $1 million in gross sales.

3.title: Lucky Break Wishbone
3.description: Ken Ahroni found a “secret formula” that allows the Lucky Break Wishbone to break just like a dried wishbone. His co made $2 million within 2 years

4.title: The Ugly Doll
4.description: The Uglydoll may not look pretty, but it has resulted in some good looking sales receipts — it’s raked in over $100 million in retail sales since its debut.

5.title: The Spork
5.description: Joachim Nordwall designed a two-ended spork for the Swedish company Light My Fire in 2003, which has sold more than 20 million units.

7.title: Antenna Balls
7.description: Jason Wall was inspired by a Jack in the Box commerical in 1997 and create some to sell to auto part store. He made $1.2 mil in 1 year.

8.title: Koosh Ball
8.description: Stillinger came up with the idea for the Koosh ball when he tied rubber bands together to create an easier-to-catch ball for his children in 1987.

9.title: Drybar
9.description: Launced in 2010 by stay a home mom, Alli Webb, and her husband, Drybar is a women's salon that specializes in blowout hairstyling for less.

10.title: Snuggie
10.description: The company declines to disclose exact sales revenue, but says 30 million blankets have been sold to date.

11.title: K'Nex
11.description: Joel Glickman's construction set added an extra dimension of wheels, pulleys and gears to more traditional concepts. Knex receives $200 million in annual sales.

13.title: Pet Rock
13.description: in April 1975, Gary Dahl came up with the idea of a pet rock when his friends complained about their own pet. Dahl sold 1.5 million Pet Rocks and became a millionaire.

14.title: Doggles
14.description: It all happened one day in 1996 when Roni Di Lullo notice that her dog couldn't play fetch well because of the glare in his eyes. Doggles made $3 million in retail sales last year.

15.title: 1-800-GOT-JUNK
15.description: In 1990, Brian Scudamore was a struggling college student looking to make some extra cash. Today, there are 173 franchises, and the company made $137 million last year.

16.title: TOMS
16.description: An overpriced pair of shoe created by Blake Mycoskie with an humanitarian purpose. It survived the recession and hasover 500 retailers were carrying the brand globally.

17.title: The million dollar homepage
17.description: From the simple idea of selling pixels of a 1000x1000 grid for $1 each, the project attracted people like flies. Alex Tew made $1,037,100 in a matter of months.

18.title: airbnb
18.description: Renting your room to strangers?! A idea that many investors in the Silcon Valley thought was crazy. In April 2014, the company has an valuation of approximately $10 billion

19.title: Obama Os & Cap’n McCains
19.description: Desparate for $, airbnb founders made special-edition Cheerios boxes for both presidential candidates with hot glue and cardboard. These boxes made them 30K to fund their co.
